comment.author: 69693706@N02
comment._content:
I think this is Percy Gordon S. Oliver who was born Macclesfield, 1899.  He entered the army in January 1918.

He survived the war, married and had a family.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69693706@N02] Thank you for this. Could you tell us where you found this information? Thanks again.

comment.author: 16830149@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/imperialwarmuseum] 
If the above information has been taken from online fee paying sites what is the guidelines regarding copywright and posting on here please?

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Hi shayes2006. That's an important question with a complex answer. Of course we would advise you to check the terms of the fee paying service. In general, copyright lapses 70 yrs after the death of the author. And 'crown copyright' for government publications lapses 50 years after publication. So most of the relevant material is out of copyright. However, digitised images of, for example, census records and military records will be subject to other license restrictions. In general, you are not allowed to post these images on Flickr (or elsewhere) but you can share the information you read from them. I hope that makes sense -- I'm sure we'll be revisiting and further clarifying this point over the coming weeks. Many thanks.

comment.author: 69645150@N05
comment._content:
Percy Gordon S Oliver - a driver in the French Red Cross.
Born in 1899 at Bollington, Cheshire, son of Edmund and his wife Florence.
He married Kathleen J Parsons at St George, Hanover Square in 1923.

comment.author: 16830149@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the clarification. Taken from www.familysearch.org Name: Percy Gordon Stanley Oliver Record Place: Prestbury, Wellington Road Wesleyan Methodist Chapel, Bollington, Cheshire Birth: 10 Oct 1889 Baptism Date: 29 Oct 1899 Father's Name: Edmund Lomas Oliver Mother's Name: Florence Adelaide Oliver Page Number: 57 Image Number: 00825 Film Number: 2299418 Digital Folder Number: 4020669

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Born in 1899 the 1901 census records him, one year old, the [then] youngest child of- as previously stated, Edmund Lomas Oliver [b.1866 Bollington Cheshire d. 26/7/1953] and Florence Adelaide Oliver [b.1871, Leeds, West Yorks. d.29/10/1956].He is living at Wellington Road, Bollinton with his older sisters Rosina Muriel [b. 1896 d.1994], Kathleen Mary [b.1898 d.1945] and older brother [Ian]Maurice Lomas. THere had been an older brother, John Norman, who had died in infancy and there would also be a younger brother, Peter.
His older brother also served in the Great War and served with the South Staffs and was wounded in 1918 [at Kemmel].
His family were the owners of Thomas Oliver & Sons, Cotton Spinners who operated the Waterhouse Mill, Bollington. Their house, Waterhouse, was adjacent to the mill. Although the mill was demolished in 1962, the house survives part of it in use as the Bollington Medical Centre.
Percy joined the family firm after his service. Died 1957.
Below is a thumb-nail photo of the house.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6487485969/in/photostream]

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Information about Waterhouse Mill, Bollington with mention of its 150-year history as of 1940, is here happy-valley.org.uk/history/mill-waterhouse.htm Cotton spinning ceased on 5th August 1960 and, as mentioned above, most buildings were demolished in 1962. Genealogical information for the Lomas Oliver family can be accessed here but dates prove inaccurate. www.happy-valley.org.uk/history/mill-waterhouse.htm#people happy-valley.org.uk/families/ps01/ps01_449.htm FreeBMD Edmund L Oliver birth reg 1st qr 1866 Macclesfield 8a 92 Florence Adelaide Flitch birth reg 2nd qr 1870 Leeds 9b 538 Note: not 1871 Ian Maurice L Oliver birth reg 4th qr 1898 Macclesfield 8a 110 Percy Gordon S Oliver birth reg 4th qr 1899 Macclesfield 8a 115
